questions.text: A newborn baby refuses breast milk since the 2nd day of birth but accepts glucose water. He develops vomiting and severe jaundice by the 5th day. Benedict's test was positive for urine and blood glucose was low. The most likely cause is due to the deficiency of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The above clinical features on ingestion of breastmilk at birth suggest classical galactosemia, a disorder of galactose metabolism. Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency leads to classical galactosemia.

questions.text: A patient presents with a clinical scenario of obstructive jaundice. Which of the following results can be seen on Van der bergh's reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

In a patient with obstructive jaundice , van der bergh reaction gives direct positive result due to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

choices.text: Treatment with folate unmasking pyridoxine deficiency
Deficiency of folate reductase in CNS
Folate therapy using the B12 stores

questions.text: A patient presented with symptoms of peripheral neuropathy and macrocytic anemia. She was given folate 5mg and the blood picture improved. However, the neurologic manifestations were aggravated. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The most likely cause is folate therapy which used up the B12 stores, aggravating the symptoms.

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaint of abdominal pain. Routine investigations were unremarkable. On observation, the urine turned black on standing. Which of the following enzymes is likely to be defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

The urine turning to black in colour on exposure to air is suggestive of alkaptonuria which occurs due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase enzyme.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was on maize as a staple diet for a prolonged period. He presented with diarrhoea and lesion over his neck as shown in the image below. The condition occurs due to deficiency of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

The above history and clinical features suggest niacin/vitamin B3 deficiency. Excessive consumption of maize-based diets can cause pellagra. Corn/Maize has low levels of niacin and tryptophan. Jowar has high leucine content which inhibits QPRTase, an enzyme in the synthesis of Niacin.

questions.text: An infant presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. Which of the following is accumulated in the brain in cerebrohepatorenal syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome or Zellweger's syndrome is characterized by the accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acid, abnormalities of synthesis of bile acids and a marked reduction of plasmalogens.

questions.text: In a patient with lipoprotein lipase deficiency, which of the following is increased following a fatty meal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

After a fatty meal, chylomicrons are elevated in lipoprotein lipase deficiency. Chylomicrons transport dietary lipids from the intestine to the peripheral tissues. They are synthesized in the intestine by assembling apo B-48 with lipids (mainly triacylglycerols).

questions.text: A patient presented with symptoms of delayed adaptation to vision in dark places, gritty sensation in the eyes, dry eyes, and softening of the cornea. What is the likely deficiency in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

The clinical picture of delayed adaptation to vision in dark places, gritty sensation in the eyes, dry eyes, and softening of the comea is suggestive of vitamin A deficiency in the patient. Hence retinoic acid (the active form of vitamin A) is likely to be deficient.

questions.text: A patient presented with tendon xanthomas. His lipid profile showed serum cholesterol levels to be 283 mg/dL and serum LDL to be 202 mg/dL. He was started on lovastatin. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Familial hypercholesterolemia The clinical presentation with tendon xanthomas and elevated serum LDL (low-density lipoprotein) and elevated serum cholesterol points to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia (FH).

questions.text: A patient who has been diagnosed with multiple gastrointestinal polyps and carcinoma, with a positive family history/history of hereditary non-polyposis colon carcinoma has a defect in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Mismatch repair

Mismatch repair will be defective in a patient with multiple gastrointestinal polyps and carcinoma, with a positive family history/history of hereditary non-polyposis colon carcinoma (HNPCC)/Lynch syndrome.

questions.text: A young girl presented to the OPD for examination. She is tall and thin with slender fingers, and dislocated lenses. Workup revealed cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency. Which amino acid supplement is required in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Cysteine 

The clinical picture of a tall and thin young girl with slender fingers, dislocated lenses, and cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency is suggestive of classic homocystinuria. The amino acid supplement required in this scenario is cysteine.

questions.text: A patient underwent gastrectomy for gastric adenocarcinoma. Which of the following vitamins needs to be supplemented in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Vitamin B12

A patient who has undergone gastrectomy for gastric adenocarcinoma needs to be supplemented with vitamin B12.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. The laboratory results show serum triglyceride levels > 2000 mg/dl. Which deficiency could be contributing to the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Apolipoprotein C II

The elevated triglyceride levels and symptoms of acute pancreatitis are likely related to a deficiency in apolipoprotein C II.

questions.text: After the age of 12, the boy had an intellectual disability. On examination, fingernail abrasions, excessive biting of lips, and increased levels of serum uric acid were observed. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Lesch-Nyhan disease

The above clinical scenario with findings showing self- mutilation and laboratory values of hyperuricemia is most likely suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan disease.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the OPD with complaints of persistent delayed developmental milestones, and hyperpigmented macular lesions on the body which are more pronounced on exposure to sunlight. What is the error in DNA multiplication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Nucleotide excision repair

The history points to a diagnosis of xeroderma pigmentosum. It is characterized by defective nucleotide excision repair.

questions.text: A young female comes to the emergency department after ingesting 10 tablets of Phenobarbital. Which of the following components of the ETC is inhibited by this drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Complex I to Q

Phenobarbital is a barbiturate that inhibits complex I to Q of the electron transport chain.

questions.text: A child presents to you with bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia. A trephine biopsy aspirate shows the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Glucocerebrosidase

The given clinical scenario of a child with bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and trephine biopsy showing Gaucher’s cell with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance is suggestive of Gaucher’s disease. The deficient enzyme is glucocerebrosidase (also known as beta-glucosidase).

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency is associated with a chronic alcoholic patient presenting with gum bleeding, corkscrew hair, petechial haemorrhages, poor wound healing, and generalized weakness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Vitamin C

The given clinical scenario of a chronic alcoholic patient presenting with gum bleeding, corkscrew hair, petechial haemorrhages, poor wound healing, and generalised weakness is associated with vitamin C deficiency.

questions.text: A 4-day-old neonate presented with jaundice and a bilirubin level of 5 mg/dL. The most probable cause is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Physiological jaundice

The given clinical scenario of a 4-day-old neonate presenting with a bilirubin level of 5 mg/dL is suggestive of physiological jaundice.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient with a reduced food intake over the past few months now presents with hypoglycemia. What is the most likely cause of hypoglycemia in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Impaired gluconeogenesis

The given clinical scenario of a chronic alcoholic presenting with hypoglycemia is suggestive of alcohol (ethanol) intoxication that inhibits the process of gluconeogenesis.
